section-block.rac_essential-question: How can we express ourselves through making art?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written and illustrated by Tedd Arnold
section-block.rac_book_summary: Vincent decides that white would be a good color to paint his house. But his animal neighbors have very different ideas!

section-block.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Use Tt, Aa, and Mm Alphabet Cards.
section-block.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we will review the letters Tt, Aa, and Mm.

section-block.rac_body-text: Sing “Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush,” with verses about painting, such as, “This is the way we paint the walls.”

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to read the book Vincent Paints His House by Tedd Arnold.
Pablo loves reading narratives because the stories have interesting characters!
Here is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read.
How did Vincent’s house change?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: I see the letter T in the word time. What sound does the letter T make in the word time?
Repeat after me: “Hmm.” Sometimes we say this when we need to decide something. What is Vincent planning to do?
Let’s pretend we’re Vincent. Let’s paint our house!
I see the letter a in the word and. Who can come point to the letter a in and?
I see the letter M in the word my. What sound does the letter M make in the word my?
I see the letter a in the word snake. What sound does the letter a make in the word snake?
What do you see on this page? Describe what Vincent’s house looks like.
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then use Equity Sticks to choose two or three children to respond.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Vincent’s house is painted all the colors.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud a short sentence about painting as children watch and listen.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What color does Vincent paint with?
Vincent paints with all the c_______ (colors).
Vincent paints with all the colors.
Can you name all of the colors of paint on the house?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Continue to assess children’s recognition of uppercase and lowercase letters in and out of sequence. Speed and accuracy in recognizing letters will lay a foundation for prereading and reading. Assessments will help you plan instruction based on each child’s needs.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Make Plans
section-block.rac_body-text: Start a discussion about goal-setting, by saying, Sometimes we can set goals for ourselves when we want to get better at something. Encourage children to tell about a time when they reached a goal, such as learning to tie shoelaces or learning the alphabet. Talk about each step that was needed to reach the goal.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the book Vincent Paints His House by Tedd Arnold.
Clifford enjoys setting and reaching his goals! Let’s see how Vincent sets and reaches his goal!

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
Read aloud the book and the Day 2 Prompts.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Vincent set a goal! What is Vincent’s goal? (MB)
What is Vincent’s plan? (MB)

Look at the letters in the word red. What is the first letter? What sound does the letter r make? What is the second letter? What sound does the letter e make? What is the last letter? What sound does the letter d make? Let’s put the sounds together to read the word! (red)
Why does Vincent’s plan keep changing? What does Vincent do when his plans change? (MB)
What color is the bird? Why do you think the bird asks Vincent to paint his house blue?
Look at the paints. What color is in each tube of paint? Do the colors look the same? How does Vincent classify all of his paint colors?
Vincent finishes painting his house! How does Vincent reach his goal? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw a picture to show how Vincent’s house looked after he finished painting. Talk about the tools they need to reach this goal and encourage them to plan what they want to do before they begin to create the picture.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about making a plan to create art.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Setting goals helps children take responsibility for their learning. Setting goals will guide children to develop grit. Encourage children to break the goal down into smaller steps. (Meltzer, L., 2010.)

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk with children about a time they made a prediction, or smart guess about what was going to happen later, such as the weather.
section-block.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Review Make a Prediction Strategy Card.

section-block.rac_body-text: Invite children to sing “The Alphabet Song” and stand up when the first letter of their first name is sung.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the book Vincent Paints His House by Tedd Arnold.
Pablo likes this narrative about Vincent and his house. He enjoys looking at all the different colors.
This is the guiding question I want you to think about as we read:
Why did Vincent keep changing the color of his house?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Look at the paints on this page. What kind of color is titanium? Even though this is a big word that you may not have heard before, can you tell what color titanium is? How did you figure that out? Who can tell me what letter is at the start of the word titanium?
Look at the paints on this page. What kind of color is amber? How do you know? What letter is at the start of the word amber?
The beetle likes purple. What do you know about beetles?
Look at the paints on this page. Even though this is a big word that you may have not heard before, how do you know what color manganese is? What letter is at the start of the word manganese?
What if a new animal such as a rabbit or a ladybug showed up? Can you predict what would happen next?
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Review Make a Prediction Strategy Card.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
Why did Vincent keep changing the color of his house?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then use Equity Sticks to choose children to share their ideas.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: The animals wanted the house to be different colors.
Vincent liked all of the colors.
Vincent wanted to make his animal friends happy.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to write about choosing paint colors, inviting children to suggest color words.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Everyone wanted the house to be different c________ (colors).
Everyone wanted the house to be different colors.
What words would you use to tell about Vincent?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Making predictions is an important skill because it helps children to become active thinkers. They can make predictions based on prior knowledge or what they have already read or heard. These types of connections help young readers stay interested in a story and make a story more meaningful.

section-block.rac_body-text: Lead children in a discussion about different ways to make something, such as drawing, building, painting, or using clay.
Use the song “Old MacDonald Had a Farm” and have children specifically sing about horses and what the horses say. Invite children to gallop in place.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read A Horse, of Course. It is an informational text.
Pablo loves to learn new things from informational texts about different ways to create a horse!
Vincent Paints His House and A Horse, of Course both focus on creating something amazing. Let’s see what’s the same about them!
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show Vincent Paints His House cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to our concept question:
How can we express ourselves through making art?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart, and then use these prompts to read and discuss the child-facing poster together.
Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who can point to the pictures of horses drawn on the cave wall? How are the horses the same? How are they different?
Look at this picture. The artist sculpted these horses! What material did the artist use?
Describe the painting. What do you feel when you look at it?
How is this horse different from the other horses on the poster? Have you ever seen or hit a piñata? What was inside?
If you had some clay, how would you mold the clay into a horse?

section.rac_body-text: Give each child a lump of clay and invite them to create an animal of their choice. Talk about the sensory experience of molding the clay. Invite children to share about their sculptures. Did they make a fierce tiger? A friendly kitten? Then display the completed pieces of art.
Provide a writing prompt about creating art and guide children’s responses.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: When children have opportunities to develop creative expression, the trait will feel more natural. Music, art, dance, and drama all contribute to fine motor skills, gross motor skills, and development of imagination. The creative arts help children to become curious and innovative thinkers.

section-block.rac_body-text: Challenge children to name all of the animals mentioned in the story. Invite children to act out the actions of several of the animals. For example, a child might hiss like a snake or move their fingers to imitate a spider’s legs. Have children guess what animal their classmate is acting out.
Review vocabulary that will be used today.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread Vincent Paints His House by Tedd Arnold.
Pablo likes to reread a narrative because he knows his favorite parts are coming up in the story!
This week we read about Vincent and his house of colors. As we read the book one more time, I want you to think about this guiding question:
Why was everyone happy after Vincent painted his house?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s pretend we are Vincent. Let’s get our paints ready!
Let’s name all of the colors we see on Vincent’s palette. Which color would you choose first? How does Vincent classify his colors?
What do the bubbles show between Vincent and the picture of the house? What is Vincent thinking about?
Let’s pretend we are the butterfly! Stand up and move your arms like butterfly wings.
Let’s look at Vincent’s different green paints: viridian, olive, emerald, and chartreuse. They are all green, but different! Which would you choose?
Do you think the animals are happy? Let’s celebrate! What do you like to do to celebrate when you have reached a goal? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to turn and talk about the guiding question.
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Why was everyone happy after Vincent painted his house?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, use Equity Sticks to choose two or three children to share their thoughts.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Each animal got the color it wanted.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about making art and share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How does Vincent make up his own mind while still listening to his friends?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Multilingual learners must process by analyzing sounds, words, and grammar. They must also process by using background knowledge to make meaning. Use the familiar animals in the story to help children with both types of processing.
